item.title: Marius add a quote by Kurt Vonnegut
Marius add a quote by Hunter S. Thompson
item.description: "Every now and then when your life gets complicated and the weasels start closing in, the only cure is to load up on heinous chemicals and then drive like a bastard from Hollywood to Las Vegas ... with the music at top volume and at least a pint of ether." -- Hunter S. Thompson

item.title: Marius add a quote by Hunter S. Thompson
item.description: "We can't stop here, this is bat country!" -- Hunter S. Thompson

item.title: Marius add a quote by Mark Twain
item.description: "Wagnerâ€™s music is better than it sounds." -- Mark Twain

item.title: Marius add a quote by Joseph Heller
item.description: "Actually there were many officers' clubs that Yossarian had not helped build, but he was proudest of the one on Pianosa. It was a sturdy and complex monument to his powers of determination. Yossarian never went there to help until it was finished; then he went there often, so pleased was he with the large , fine, rambling shingled building. It was a truly splendid building, and Yossarian throbbed with a mighty sense of accomplishment each time he gazed at it and reflected that none of the work that had gone into it was his." -- Joseph Heller

item.title: Marius add a quote by Joseph Heller "Catch-22"
item.description: "The bloated colonel: "Now, where were we? Read me back the last line." " 'Read me back my last line.' " read back the corporal who could take shorthand." -- Joseph Heller "Catch-22"

item.title: Marius add a quote by Alan Bennett
item.description: "We started off trying to set up a small anarchist community, but people wouldn't obey the rules." -- Alan Bennett

item.title: Marius add a quote by Neal Stephenson
item.description: "When the Deliverator puts the hammer down, shit happens." -- Neal Stephenson

item.title: Marius add a quote by James Joyce
item.description: "His heart danced upon her movements like a cork upon a tide. He heard what her eyes said to him from beneath their cowl and knew that in some dim past, whether in life or revery, he had heard their tale before." -- James Joyce
